extraction_metadata.article_title: Mobile ticketing services in the Northern Europe: Critical business model issues

extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Mobile Ticketing Services. Definition: Services that provide digital ticketing solutions for public transport through mobile devices, evolving from SMS-based single tickets to smartphone applications and seamless 'Be-In Be-Out' (BIBO) solutions, becoming platforms for combined mobility solutions that integrate mobile ticketing, bike renting, car sharing, and parking payment services.
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Started as SMS ticketing, today, mobile ticketing services become a platform for combined mobility solutions that integrate mobile ticketing, bike renting, car sharing, and parking payment services' | Page 1: 'Mobile ticketing started as premium SMS services for single tickets. With wider smartphone penetration mobile ticketing applications were introduced'

extracted_data.question_text: What synonyms or alternative terms are used in the article to refer to this software business model?
extracted_value: SMS ticketing
In-app mobile ticketing
BIBO ticketing
Be-In Be-Out ticketing
Premium SMS services
Mobile ticketing applications
Mobile ticketing apps
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Started as SMS ticketing, today, mobile ticketing services' | Page 1: 'introduction of "Be-In Be-Out" (BIBO) seamless ticketing solutions' | Page 1: 'Mobile ticketing started as premium SMS services' | Page 1: 'mobile ticketing applications were introduced'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the main vertical segment or industry where the software business model presented in the article is applied?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Public transport is an important area that is highly affecting everyday life of citizens. Mobile ticketing services contribute to making public transport smarter' | Page 1: 'Mobile ticketing started as premium SMS services for single tickets... targeted non-regular public transport passengers'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the target customer type of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'targeted non-regular public transport passengers having no travel card. Now, the majority of ticketing apps offers almost a full range of available tickets for all types of passengers' | Page 3: 'The questions covered the following interview subjects... (5) general feedback from the end-users' | Page 2: 'A few studies are focused on the problem of mobile ticketing adoption by customers'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the typical size of offering companies that adopt this software business model as described in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Large public transport companies (regional public transport authorities and operators) and various technology solution providers ranging from large mobile network operators to small technology companies
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'Swedish major regional public transport companies (SL, UL, Östgötatrafiken, Skånetrafiken, Västtrafik)' | Page 5: 'In Sweden, the unified SMS ticketing solution was provided in collaboration with national mobile network operators, which are large, established market actors. After launch of "new" SMS ticketing, unified solution was replaced by different scattered solutions, and mobile network operators were replaced by small technology companies'

extracted_data.question_text: In which geographic region was the software business model presented in the article studied or applied?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Northern Europe (specifically Sweden, Norway, Estonia, Denmark, and Lithuania)
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'we explore obstacles and challenges associated with business model (or critical business model issues) of mobile ticketing services in five Northern European countries (Sweden, Norway, Estonia, Denmark, and Lithuania)' | Page 1: 'In some Northern Europe countries mobile ticketing solutions became available starting from 2009'

extracted_data.question_text: What specific customer segment is most detailed in the article regarding the software business model?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Public transport passengers in urban areas (both regular and non-regular users, including commuters and occasional travelers/tourists)
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'The first apps did offer single tickets only and targeted non-regular public transport passengers having no travel card. Now, the majority of ticketing apps offers almost a full range of available tickets for all types of passengers' | Page 4: 'SMS tickets are not available for foreigners. SMS tickets can only be bought by people having subscription with local mobile operators. People with mobile phone subscription in other countries (e.g. tourists) cannot buy these tickets'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the type of product or service offered by the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Application
Platform
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'With wider smartphone penetration mobile ticketing applications were introduced' | Page 1: 'mobile ticketing services become a platform for combined mobility solutions that integrate mobile ticketing, bike renting, car sharing, and parking payment services'

extracted_value: Mobile (SMS)
Mobile (smartphone applications for Android and iPhone)

The segment of Windows phone users is very small, and in the majority of cases this group of customers is not considered'

Prepaid credits (period tickets)

extracted_data.extracted_value: SEK (Swedish Krona) mentioned for Swedish cases; billing per transaction or monthly invoices

extracted_data.extracted_value: Standalone product (mobile ticketing as a channel/interface to existing public transport services)

extracted_data.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Time and place independent service access, reduced queuing, mobility, convenience, fast ticketing avoiding queues to vending machines, combined mobility solutions
Customer Segment: Public transport passengers (all types including non-regular users, commuters, smartphone users)
Channels: Mobile apps (Android, iPhone), SMS services
Key Partnerships: SMS aggregators, ticket providers, mobile network operators, payment processors, banks, providers of ticketing solutions, technology solution providers
Revenue Streams: Transaction fees, premium SMS payments, subscription billing

Cost Structure: Service fees (15-30% for mobile operators), payment service provider fees, technical solution provider fees, infrastructure costs (optical readers), high transaction costs, credit card fraud costs
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'For mobile ticketing services, mobility "includes time and place independent service access, reduced queuing, and substituting for other services"' | Page 7: 'For customers, mobile ticketing means a fast and convenient way to get a ticket anytime avoiding queues to ticket vending machines' | Page 1: 'targeted non-regular public transport passengers' and 'all types of passengers' | Page 3: 'two types of actors are needed: SMS aggregators and ticket providers (e.g. Plusdial, UnWire, Mobill, and IPX in different regions of Sweden, and UnWire in Copenhagen) that provide technology solution, and mobile network operators that act as payment processors' | Page 5: 'The mobile operators' service fee is considered as quite high (about 15–30%)' | Page 6: 'the major sources of costs for in app ticketing are: (i) higher percentage of commissions; and (ii) service fees set by payment service providers and/or technical solution providers'

extracted_data.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?
extracted_value: Public Transport Companies | Service providers and platform operators | Contract with technology providers and payment processors through procurement, sell tickets to passengers | Manage relationships with all ecosystem actors

SMS Aggregators/Ticket Providers (e.g., Plusdial, UnWire, Mobill, IPX) | Technology solution providers | Provide technical solution for ticketing | Work with payment processors and public transport companies

Mobile Network Operators (e.g., Telia, Tre, Bite Lietuva) | Payment processors (SMS) and billing providers | Include SMS ticket payments in customer bills, later excluded from some markets | Interact with customers and aggregators

Payment Processors (e.g., Accumulate, Payair, Nets, PayEx, Seamless, WyWallet) | Handle payment transactions | Process card, invoice, and mobile payments | Connect customers with public transport companies
Banks (e.g., Swedbank, DNB, Danske Bank) | Payment service providers | Offer Bank Link and card payment processing | Process financial transactions
Technology Solution Providers (e.g., Jiffi, Ridango, Samtrafiken) | Ticketing system developers | Develop BIBO and in-app solutions | Integrate with transport systems
Passengers/End-users | Customers | Purchase and use mobile tickets | Pay for services through various channels
City Administration | Regulatory/oversight bodies | Coordinate public transport policies | Interact with transport companies
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'more than 30 interviews were carried out with different types of actors. This includes: (1) mobile network operators (Telia and Tre); (2) Swedish major regional public transport companies (SL, UL, Östgötatrafiken, Skånetrafiken, Västtrafik); (3) payment processors (Accumulate, Payair, Nets, PayEx, Seamless, WyWallet); (4) a bank (Swedbank); and (5) providers of mobile ticket technology solutions (UnWire, Mobill, and Samtrafiken)' | Page 3: 'For service provision, two types of actors are needed: SMS aggregators and ticket providers (e.g. Plusdial, UnWire, Mobill, and IPX in different regions of Sweden, and UnWire in Copenhagen) that provide technology solution, and mobile network operators that act as payment processors' | Page 4: 'These actors are contracted through procurement process'

extracted_data.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Make public transport smarter
Reach wide scale penetration (many people use public transport)
Time and place independent service access
Reduced queuing for customers
Reduced amount of cash for transport companies
Convenient ticketing integrated with added value services
Cheaper to maintain in open ticketing systems (no need for infrastructure)
Fast and convenient way to get tickets avoiding queues
Integration with combined mobility solutions
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Mobile ticketing services contribute to making public transport smarter and have a potential to reach wide scale penetration, since many people use public transport' | Page 2: 'mobility "includes time and place independent service access, reduced queuing, and substituting for other services"' | Page 7: 'Some examples of advantages for public transport companies are reduced amount of cash, convenient ticketing integrated with added value services. In the case of open ticketing system, mobile ticketing is much cheaper to maintain since there is no need for infrastructure. For customers, mobile ticketing means a fast and convenient way to get a ticket anytime avoiding queues to ticket vending machines'

extracted_data.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Open ticketing system (no validation infrastructure needed) → Lower costs and easier implementation
Offering full range of tickets (not just single tickets) → Serves all passenger types and increases market share
Multiple payment options → Broader customer accessibility
Simple service design (original SMS) → High popularity among passengers
Additional services integration (route planning, real-time info) → Enhanced value proposition
Strong partnerships with established actors → Better service reliability (original unified SMS solution)
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'The service is simple and highly popular among public transport passengers' | Page 7: 'In the case of open ticketing system, mobile ticketing is much cheaper to maintain since there is no need for infrastructure' | Page 4: 'Mobile ticketing allows additional services. Route planning and real-time travel information are the most common' | Page 7: 'Ruter is extremely successful with mobile ticketing in Oslo. The share of mobile tickets is more than 40%, and it is constantly growing'

extracted_data.question_text: What prerequisites or conditions are necessary for the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Mobile phone subscription with local operator → Required for SMS ticketing services
Smartphone ownership → Required for in-app and BIBO ticketing
Payment account/registration → Required for 'new' SMS and in-app services
Technical integration with public transport systems → Required for all mobile ticketing types
Payment service provider partnership → Required for transaction processing
Optical readers infrastructure → Required for barrier systems with period tickets
Payment services license → Regulatory requirement for payment handling
Customer identity verification → Regulatory requirement to prevent money laundering
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'SMS tickets can only be bought by people having subscription with local mobile operators' | Page 5: 'Customers using feature phones cannot buy an app ticket' | Page 4: 'The major change related to "new" SMS ticketing solutions was a need for customer to register and open an account with payment service providers' | Page 4: 'The provision of mobile ticketing requires a technical solution integrated with public transport system and payment service provider' | Page 4: 'changes in regulation: (1) a license became mandatory in order to handle digital payments, and (2) payment service providers were required to know the identity of persons making payments to prevent "money laundry"'

extracted_data.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: SMS ticketing excludes foreigners/tourists → Limited to local mobile operator subscribers
In-app ticketing excludes feature phone users → Requires smartphones
Windows phone users often excluded → Small market share, apps not developed
Regulatory requirements limit actors → License mandatory for payment handling, identity verification required
Closed ticketing systems require infrastructure investment → Cannot offer period tickets without optical readers
Smartphone characteristics not controllable → NFC in iPhones only through Apple Pay
Transaction speed limitations → Mobile payments too slow for high-volume subway gates (need ~400ms)
Battery dependency → Service unavailable when phone dies
No common BLE standard → BIBO implementation challenges
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'SMS tickets are not available for foreigners. SMS tickets can only be bought by people having subscription with local mobile operators. People with mobile phone subscription in other countries (e.g. tourists) cannot buy these tickets' | Page 5: 'Customers using feature phones cannot buy an app ticket. Majority of companies do not provide apps for Windows phone users due to small share of these phones in the market' | Page 4: 'changes in regulation: (1) a license became mandatory in order to handle digital payments, and (2) payment service providers were required to know the identity of persons making payments' | Page 5: 'The speed of payment validation is critical for transportation in large cities where big numbers of people pass through the subway gates. NFC-enabled travel cards can ensure this speed (it is about 400 milliseconds). Payments taking longer time and requiring PIN-code entering are not acceptable at gates' | Page 6: 'Smartphones are not under control of public transport companies (e.g. NFC used in iPhone's can only be used through Apple Pay system)'

extracted_data.question_text: What challenges are identified in implementing the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_value: SERVICE DOMAIN: Small mobile ticket assortment (mainly single tickets initially), exclusion of certain customer groups (foreigners, feature phone users, Windows users), inconvenient service (new SMS requiring registration), small market share (3-7% in most cases)

TECHNOLOGY DOMAIN: Service reliability not 100%, worse travelling statistics (no travel data), ticket security/falsification issues, transaction speed too slow for gates, need for infrastructure investment, discharging phone battery, system hacking vulnerability, smartphone characteristics not controllable, lack of common BLE standard
ORGANIZATION DOMAIN: Change of value network actors (mobile operators replaced by small companies in Sweden), weaker relationships between parties

FINANCE DOMAIN: High service costs (15-30% fees), higher commissions and service fees, credit card fraud, high transaction costs for single tickets, pricing policy favoring plastic cards over mobile tickets
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'in some Northern European countries, the share of mobile ticket sales does not exceed 10 percent' | Page 4-6: 'Small mobile ticket assortment. SMS tickets were mainly single tickets... Small market share. In Sweden, after not successful experience of "new" SMS ticketing, the share of mobile ticketing remains rather low, for example, 3% of all sales at SL, 5% at Skånetrafiken, 7% at Västtrafik' | Page 5: 'Worse travelling statistics. In both open and closed ticketing systems, SMS ticketing solution does not provide travel data' | Page 5: 'Ticket security issues. SMS ticket are easy to falsify' | Page 5: 'The mobile operators' service fee is considered as quite high (about 15–30%)' | Page 5: 'Change of value network actors. In Sweden, the unified SMS ticketing solution was provided in collaboration with national mobile network operators, which are large, established market actors. After launch of "new" SMS ticketing, unified solution was replaced by different scattered solutions, and mobile network operators were replaced by small technology companies'

extracted_data.question_text: What practices are used to mitigate challenges of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Installing optical readers → Enables period tickets in apps and provides travel statistics → Expanded ticket assortment
Introducing passenger counting systems → Addresses lack of travel data → Improved route planning data
Offering charging on-board → Mitigates battery discharge problem → Attempted but phones charge too slowly
Providing portable chargers to inspectors → Helps passengers with dead batteries → Not successful due to slow charging
Running pilot tests (BIBO systems) → Tests new solutions before full deployment → Learning and optimization
Contracting through procurement process → Ensures clear actor roles and responsibilities → Defined relationships
Offering multiple payment options → Increases accessibility → Broader customer reach
Price policy directing to plastic cards → Manages costs and fraud risks → 10-40% discounts for card users
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 5: 'With installation of mobile ticket readers, recently updated apps of some companies (Karlstadbuss, Skånetrafiken, and Västtrafik) started offering longer period tickets' | Page 5: 'installation of mobile ticket readers will improve the situation. Another option is introduction of buses with passengers' counting systems' | Page 5: 'in order to help their customers, in some cases ticket control inspectors have portable charges, but their experience shows that the phones are charging too slow and this practice is not successful. One way to solve this problem is to have the opportunity to charge phones on-board' | Page 4: 'Ruter runs a pilot tests on one of bus lines in Oslo, and Jiffi pilots are running in Tallinn and Tartu' | Page 6: 'With the help of price policy, most of public transport companies in Sweden direct the customer choice towards use of pre-paid smart cards (e.g. single ticket in Stockholm bought with a card costs 30 SEK, and 43 SEK with mobile app, Blekingetrafiken and Länstrafiken Kronaberg offer 20% and Skånetrafiken offers 10% discount if buying single tickets with pre-paid card)'

extracted_data.question_text: What metrics and quantitative results are reported in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 5: 'In Sweden, after not successful experience of "new" SMS ticketing, the share of mobile ticketing remains rather low, for example, 3% of all sales at SL, 5% at Skånetrafiken, 7% at Västtrafik (in 2016). Due to limited payment options, the market share of mTicket in Lithuania is 3%' | Page 7: 'Ruter is extremely successful with mobile ticketing in Oslo. The share of mobile tickets is more than 40%, and it is constantly growing' | Page 5: 'The mobile operators' service fee is considered as quite high (about 15–30%)' | Page 6: 'single ticket in Stockholm bought with a card costs 30 SEK, and 43 SEK with mobile app' | Page 5: 'NFC-enabled travel cards can ensure this speed (it is about 400 milliseconds)' | Page 5: 'This is a reason preventing some people from using in-app mobile ticketing (19% according to Ruter's survey)' | Page 3: 'During these years, more than 30 interviews were carried out' and 'More than 20 interviews were conducted'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the temporal period and maturity of the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Observed period: 2009-2017 (SMS ticketing launched 2009, apps introduced 2013-2014, BIBO in pilot phase 2015-2017). Maturity status: Growing (evolving from SMS to apps to BIBO, but facing adoption challenges with <10% penetration in most markets except Norway with >40%)
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'In some Northern Europe countries mobile ticketing solutions became available starting from 2009' | Page 3: 'SMS ticketing was commercially launched by local public transport companies in Sweden and Copenhagen around 2009' | Page 4: 'Around 2013–2014 public transport companies started introduction of mobile ticketing apps. First, only single tickets were available in these apps. Currently (by 2017), the majority of apps offer partial or almost full range of period tickets' | Page 4: 'Ruter runs a pilot tests on one of bus lines in Oslo, and Jiffi pilots are running in Tallinn and Tartu' | Page 1: 'Notable trends in mobile ticketing are introduction of "Be-In Be-Out" (BIBO) seamless ticketing solutions'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the type of evidence presented in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Multiple cases (qualitative multiple case study across five Northern European countries with >50 interviews)
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'Use of multiple case studies is more beneficial than single case study because it enables cross-case analysis and more accurate generalization of findings' | Page 3: 'In this study, we apply an exploratory approach in order to identify challenges related to business models of mobile ticketing services. The research is qualitative. Based on used technology, we specified three types of mobile ticketing services: SMS, in-app, and BIBO. Description of these services is generalised using empiric data from mobile ticketing cases in five Northern European countries' | Page 3: 'During these years, more than 30 interviews were carried out with different types of actors... More than 20 interviews were conducted'

extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'Swedish major regional public transport companies (SL, UL, Östgötatrafiken, Skånetrafiken, Västtrafik); (3) payment processors (Accumulate, Payair, Nets, PayEx, Seamless, WyWallet); (4) a bank (Swedbank); and (5) providers of mobile ticket technology solutions (UnWire, Mobill, and Samtrafiken)' | Page 3-4: 'public transport companies operating in Sweden: SL, UL, Östgötatrafiken, Skånetrafiken, Västtrafik... Norway: Ruter and Skyss... Copenhagen Metro and Movia... Estonia: Jiffi and Ridango... Lithuania: Susisiekimo Paslaugos' | Page 7: 'Ruter is extremely successful with mobile ticketing in Oslo. The share of mobile tickets is more than 40%'

extracted_data.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: SMS ticketing (Premium SMS) → First generation: single tickets purchased via premium SMS, payment through mobile operator billing, simple but limited assortment
'New' SMS ticketing (Sweden post-2012) → Second generation: required customer registration and account with payment providers due to regulatory changes, led to dramatic decrease in usage

In-app mobile ticketing → Third generation: smartphone applications for Android/iPhone, initially single tickets then expanded to period tickets, multiple payment options (cards, invoices, mobile billing, bank links)

BIBO (Be-In Be-Out) ticketing → Fourth generation/emerging: automated fare collection using BLE beacons and micro-location, seamlessly starts/stops tickets based on vehicle entry/exit, pay-as-you-use model, currently in pilot phase
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Mobile ticketing started as premium SMS services for single tickets. With wider smartphone penetration mobile ticketing applications were introduced... Notable trends in mobile ticketing are introduction of "Be-In Be-Out" (BIBO) seamless ticketing solutions' | Page 3-4: 'we specified three types of mobile ticketing services: SMS, in-app, and BIBO' | Page 4: 'The major change related to "new" SMS ticketing solutions was a need for customer to register and open an account with payment service providers. Service users accepted this negatively and volumes of SMS ticket sales dramatically decreased' | Page 4: 'This is as innovative approach to ticketing. It represents an automated fare collection system based on BLE beacons and micro-location technology. This technology detects when passengers enter and exit the public transit vehicle and seamlessly starts the ticket on the ticketing app, and stops when the customer leaves the bus'

extracted_data.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Combined mobility solutions integrating multiple services (ticketing, bike renting, car sharing, parking) → Foundation: current trend showing platform evolution
BIBO next-generation ticketing with seamless entry/exit → Foundation: pilot tests running, addresses travel statistics and pricing challenges
Contactless payments integration → Foundation: mentioned as notable trend
Infrastructure investment in optical readers → Foundation: companies installing or planning to install for period tickets and statistics
Phone charging on-board vehicles → Foundation: public transport companies exploring to address battery concern
Smarter pricing based on actual usage data → Foundation: advantage of BIBO systems providing clear passenger travel data
Need for global agreements on standards and transaction costs → Foundation: identified as challenges that cannot be solved locally
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'today, mobile ticketing services become a platform for combined mobility solutions that integrate mobile ticketing, bike renting, car sharing, and parking payment services' | Page 1: 'Notable trends in mobile ticketing are introduction of "Be-In Be-Out" (BIBO) seamless ticketing solutions, contactless payments, and combined mobility solutions' | Page 4: 'The major advantage of such system is a clear data about passenger travels that would help to improve and optimise route planning. Another advantage is smarter pricing' | Page 5: 'Companies are installing or have plans to install optical readers in the near future' | Page 7: 'Public transport companies are looking into new transport vehicles providing phone charging opportunity on-board' | Page 7: 'Development of new generation mobile ticketing solutions (e.g. BIBO) may help to overcome some technology challenges (i.e. lack of travel statistics) and reduce the cost of ticketing service infrastructure' | Page 7: 'some challenges (e.g. high transaction cost, lack of unified standards, smartphone characteristics) cannot be solved locally and require global agreements'
